awd_titl_txt: Conference: Increasing student participation in the American Ecological Engineering Society 2024 conference
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecological Engineering has been defined as “the design of sustainable ecosystems that integrate human society with the natural environment for the benefit of both” (Mitsch, 2012). Ecological engineering incorporates the disciplines of ecology and engineering to solve environmental problems and to design, build, and restore systems that provide long-term economic, environmental, and social benefits. As a field that seeks to integrate knowledge from across diverse fields to address today’s challenges, Ecological Engineering is an example of Growing Convergence Research, one of NSF’s 10 Big Ideas. This conference grant will increase student participation in the American Ecological Engineering Society (AEES) 2024 conference, deepening student engagement and ownership in the Ecological Engineering discipline. The funds will be used to support student activities at the 2024 annual meeting of AEES at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Virginia. The conference theme is: Ecological Engineering & Design: Launching a New Era, to emphasize the anticipated approval of ABET criteria, completion of the Ecological Engineering body of knowledge, and updated Certified Ecological Designers (CED) training. 

This conference is expected to have approximately 200 to 225 attendees, nearly half of which are expected to be university students studying fields related to Ecological Engineering. By providing students with accommodation scholarships, presentation opportunities, and professional networking opportunities, this conference will directly contribute to NSF’s major initiative in Broadening Participation in STEM. Moreover, as the meeting theme is “Ecological Engineering & Design: Launching a New Era", this topic will provide an opportunity for students to learn how their field is advancing and will excite them in learning how the field is addressing some of society’s most pressing issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funds from this grant were used to support student activities at the 2024 annual meeting of the American Ecological Engineering Society (AEES) at Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, Virginia. The conference theme was Ecological Engineering & Design: Launching a New Era, to emphasize the anticipated approval of ABET criteria (the criteria were approved), development of the Ecological Engineering body of knowledge, and updated Certified Ecological Designer (CED) training. In total, there were 83 student participants (out of 172 attendees), who were directly exposed to state-of-the-art research, emerging dialogue about the role of diverse perspectives in engineering practice, and to an internationally recognized network of ecological engineers to inspire their development and careers in the profession. This conference provided critical student-targeted opportunities, including travel scholarships to increase the variety of students attending the conference (based on financial need, background, etc.), social networking events, a presentation competition, and a diverse perspectives working session. Additionally, the grant supported a session by the Student Chapter Committee on developing AEES student clubs at universities and a student social to encourage networking among student members. Both the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality and the U.S. Forest Service participated in the conference to recruit students for internships and full-time employment. 

This grant provided travel, lodging, and registration funds for 25 students external to Virginia Tech to attend the conference. Additionally, this grant covered registration costs for 23 students internal to Virginia Tech who volunteered and helped with various aspects of running the conference.

The conference as a whole provided an opportunity for students to present their research, network, and engage with the Ecological Engineering community. In a post-conference follow-up survey for funded student participants, all respondents rated their overall experience at the conference as good or excellent. Respondents expressed appreciation for the breadth and depth of topics represented in the technical sessions, as well as the wide variety of fieldtrip opportunities, which contributed to their professional development. Students also indicated that they were able to form valuable new professional connections and received insightful feedback on their own presented research. Several students remarked upon the welcoming and inclusive atmosphere of the conference.
